response:
Young woman with subacute cerebellar syndrome plus unilateral optic neuropathy suggests inflammatory CNS demyelination, most likely relapsing-remitting MS or a clinically isolated demyelinating syndrome; NMOSD and MOGAD are important alternatives. The tempo and age make stroke and structural lesions less likely but they must be excluded, as should autoimmune/paraneoplastic and metabolic causes of cerebellar ataxia.

differential_diagnosis = ["Relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis", "Clinically isolated syndrome due to central nervous system demyelination", "Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder", "Myelin-oligodendrocyte-glycoprotein antibody-associated disease", "Right cerebellar space-occupying lesion (e.g. low-grade glioma or metastasis)", "Autoimmune or paraneoplastic cerebellitis", "Ischaemic stroke of the right cerebellar hemisphere (e.g. PICA or SCA territory)", "Toxic or metabolic cerebellar degeneration (e.g. alcohol, phenytoin, gluten ataxia, vitamin B12 deficiency)"]
